#â€‹771 â€” February 3, 2026

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Four Heavyweights Drop Updates

Four stalwarts of the JavaScript ecosystem all shipped notable releases this week, and odds are you're using at least one of them:

  • Gatsby v5.16 proves Gatsby, once considered neck-and-neck with Next.js in the React world, is not 'dead'. The headline feature is React 19Â support.

  • Babel 7 just shipped its final release. "After years in the making, Babel 8 is finally ready," in release candidate form, atÂ least.

  • Rspress 2.0 is a major release for the high-performance Rust-powered, but JavaScript-facing, static siteÂ generator.

  • Lodash 4.17.23 sounds minor, but it's a 'security reset' for the still heavily used utility library and is designed to provide a base for a longerÂ future.

Only Fools Write Tests â€” Modern engineering teams like Notion, Dropbox, Wiz, and LaunchDarkly use Meticulous to maintain E2E UI tests that cover every edge case of your webÂ app.

Meticulous sponsor

ğŸ¦€Â OpenClaw: The Runaway AI Assistant â€” An intense week for a new open source TypeScript project: 150k stars on GitHub, hordes buying Mac Minis to run it, two rebrands (it was originally Clawdbot), and an ecosystem of projects the agents use autonomously (e.g. an entire social network). Another example of TypeScript at the heart of the AIÂ boom.

Peter Steinberger

IN BRIEF:

  • The popular JSBin collaborative JavaScript pastebin went down for a few days and Remy Sharp shares the war story of what happened.

  • ğŸ”’ The OpenJS Foundation has shared an annual report covering its efforts in securing the JSÂ ecosystem.

  • Angular is changing components' default change detection strategy.

  • Both Astro and Svelte have shared monthly roundups of what'sÂ new.

RELEASES:

  • Node.js v25.6.0 (Current) â€“ async_hooks can now skip Promise hooks to reduce overhead. Plus, URL parsing now supports UnicodeÂ 17.

  • jQuery UI 1.14.2 â€“ The legacy UI library gets its first update in over a year and now works with jQueryÂ 4.0.

  • Bun v1.3.8 â€“ Say hello to native MarkdownÂ parsing.

  • Astro 5.17, ESLint 10.0.0-rc2, tRPC v11.9.0, Lexical 0.40.0, Reka UI 2.8 (formerly RadixÂ Vue)

ğŸ“–Â  Articles and Videos

â‰ï¸Â How Not to Parse Numbers in JavaScript â€” Why use a proper locale-aware API to parse numbers when you can hand-roll a maze of string splits, separator swaps, and implicit type coercions that silently break on edgeÂ cases?

Remy Porter (The Daily WTF)

ğŸ“‰Â Node.js 16 to 25 Benchmarked Version-by-Version â€” The jumps in performance in various areas are striking (with Node 25, especially), with other areas getting more modestÂ gains.

RepoFlow

A Practical Checklist for B2B Enterprise Readiness â€” Measure gaps in auth, admin UX, security, monitoring, and architecture for landing enterprise customers. DownloadÂ today!

Descope sponsor

Explicit Resource Management in JavaScript â€” You can use using for deterministic cleanup, calling Symbol.dispose/asyncDispose at scope exit without try/finally. A small fix for leaks and forgotten teardowns in streams, observers, locks, and similarÂ APIs.

Matt Smith

The History of C# and TypeScript with Anders Hejlsberg â€” GitHub interviewed the creator of both C# and TypeScript about his career, why TypeScript was created in the first place, some internal Microsoft politics, as well as the ongoing Go port of the TypeScriptÂ compiler. There's a video of the full interview, as well as 'seven learnings' boiled down in writtenÂ form.

GitHub

ğŸ“„ My Opinionated ESLint Setup for Vue Projects â€“ Packed with examples to pick and chooseÂ from. Alexander Opalic

ğŸ“„ A Scroll-Revealed WebGL Gallery with GSAP, Three.js, Astro and Barba.js â€“ Striking visual image reveal effect with a liveÂ demo. Chakib Mazouni

ğŸ“„ Predicting Math.random() in Firefox Using Z3 SMT-Solver Dennis Yurichev

ğŸ¤ Securing npm is Table Stakes Nicholas C. Zakas (Changelog Podcast)

ğŸ“„ Building a Simple RSS Aggregator with Astro Raymond Camden

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Heat.js 5.0: A Flexible Heat Map Rendering Solution â€” Generate customized interactive heatmaps (think GitHub contributions graph), or render heatmaps as lines and bar charts. The site is packed with demos to enjoy. GitHubÂ repo.

William Troup

Building an MCP Server? Don't Roll Your Own Auth â€” WorkOS AuthKit handles OAuth 2.1 flows so your MCP server just verifies tokens. Control which tools AI agentsÂ access.

WorkOS sponsor

ğŸ•’Â Croner 10.0: Cron-Style Triggers and Evaluation â€” Trigger functions on any cron schedule using cron syntax. It can also evaluate cron expressions to give you a list of upcoming times. v10.0 brings full OCPS (Open Cron Pattern Specification) 1.4 compliance and even more schedulingÂ options.

Hexagon

ğŸ—“ï¸Â DayFlow: A Full Calendar Component for React â€” A React-only feature-rich calendar component with drag-and-drop, multiple views, and all the usual GCal-style richness. Its infinite scrolling feature is nifty. GitHubÂ repo.

DayFlow Contributors

Tsonic: A TypeScript to C# Transpiler â€” The idea is for creating native executables that run on .NET. Iâ€™ve not tested it as Iâ€™m not in that ecosystem but itâ€™s an interestingÂ idea.

Jeswin

  • ğŸ“„ EmbedPDF 2.4 â€“ Framework-agnostic JavaScript PDF viewer. (Demo.)

  • JavaScriptKit v0.40 â€“ Swift framework for interacting with JS viaÂ WASM.

  • StackBlur.js 3.0 â€“ Long-standing Gaussian blur library; now usingÂ ESM.

  • Knip 5.83 â€“ Finds and fixes unused files, dependencies andÂ exports.

  • ğŸ“„ jsPDF 4.1 â€“ Generate PDFs directly in JavaScript. (Demo.)

  • qrcode.vue 3.8 â€“ Vue.js component to generate QRÂ codes.

  • focus-trap 8.0 â€“ Trap focus within a DOM node. (Demo.)

ğŸ“¢Â  Elsewhere in the ecosystem

Some other interesting tidbits in the broader landscape:

  • GitHub is exploring solutions to tackle low-quality contributions, which could include giving you the option to disable PRs entirely or at least restrict them to collaborators. Got opinions? Join theÂ discussion.

  • How to throttle individual network requests in Chrome, rather than at a global level. Ideal for testing what happens when your dependencies load veryÂ slooooooowwwwwly....

  • ğŸ¤– OpenAI has released a desktop version of its agentic-coding Codex app. macOS only for now, though someone used Codex to port itself to Linux..Â ğŸ˜‚

  • âš ï¸ If you're a Windows user using the popular Notepad++ editor, you might want to double check your install as the project suffered a suspected state-sponsored hijack inÂ 2025.

  • svelteesp32 is a curious project for embedding Svelte, React, Angular or Vue frontends into ESP32 microcontrollerÂ apps.

#â€‹770 â€” January 27, 2026

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

item.title: ã€A big week for jQueryã€‘jQuery é‡è¦çš„ä¸€å‘¨
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹769 â€” January 20, 2026

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

jQuery 4.0 Released â€” 20 years on from its original release, the ever-popular (in terms of actual usage) library reaches 4.0 with a migration to ES modules (compatible with modern build tools) along with dropping support for IE 10 and older. With jQuery being a popular guest in our newsletters in the early years, itâ€™s fantastic to see it pop back for a quickÂ visit.

Timmy Willison

ğŸ’¡ If you're using jQuery, you'll find jQuery Migrate, an official tool to help you upgrade, useful. jQuery in 2026 is a somewhat legacy choice, though, and you might not need jQuery atÂ all..

Add Excel-like Spreadsheet Functionality to Your JavaScript Apps â€” SpreadJS is the industry-leading JavaScript spreadsheet for adding advanced spreadsheet features to your enterprise apps. Build finance, analysis, budget, and other apps. Excel I/O, 500+ calc functions, tables, charts, and more. View demosÂ now.

SpreadJS from MESCIUS inc sponsor

Astro is Joining Cloudflare â€” Big news in the Web framework space as the team behind the popular Astro framework (the beta of v6.0 is now available) is headed to Cloudflare. Few major frameworks are now not under the wing of a largerÂ entity.

Schott and Irvine-Broque

IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸ•’ Temporal Playground is an online sandbox for playing around with the Temporal API.

  • Svelte has released patches for five vulnerabilities affecting the SvelteÂ ecosystem.

  • ğŸ¤– Ryan Dahl, creator of both Node.js and Deno, says on X that "the era of humans writing code is over" and "That's not to say SWEs don't have work to do, but writing syntax directly is not it." I hope not, but these are interestingÂ times!

RELEASES:

  • Electron 40.0 â€“ The popular cross-platform desktop app framework upgrades to Chromium 144, V8 14.4, and NodeÂ 24.11.1.

  • Node.js v25.4.0 (Current) â€“ require(esm) is now marked asÂ stable.

  • React Native Windows 0.81, Aurelia 2 RC, Deno 2.6.5

ğŸ“–Â  Articles and Videos

ASCII Characters Are Not Pixels: A Deep Dive Into ASCIIÂ Rendering â€” Alex digs deep into getting ASCII-based graphics rendering just right with JavaScript, complete with examples of the algorithms used and numerousÂ demos. The neatest technical blog post Iâ€™ve seen so far thisÂ year.

Alex Harri

JavaScript Now a First-Class Citizen in Aspire â€” Aspire is a Microsoft framework for orchestrating the deployment of distributed apps. Originally just for .NET, Aspire 13 now makes JavaScript a first-class citizen, so you can run Vite and full-stack JS apps with service discovery, telemetry, and production-readyÂ containers.

Microsoft

Breakpoints and console.log Is the Past, Time Travel Is the Future â€” 15x faster JavaScript debugging than with breakpoints and console.log, supports Vitest, jest, Karma, Jasmine, andÂ more.

Wallaby Team sponsor

Introducing the <geolocation> Element â€” Chrome 144 introduces a new <geolocation> element for requesting user location data, moving away from a JavaScript-triggered prompt.

Viana, Le, Steiner

ğŸ“„ Bootstrapping Bun â€“ â€œMy journey running the build system for Bun â€¦ without relying on any of its usual binary dependencies â€” namelyÂ itself.â€ Bradley Walters

ğŸ“„ Building a Scroll-Driven Dual-Wave Text Animation with GSAP Valentin Descombes

ğŸ“„ How the Electron Team Improved Window Resize Behavior Niklas Wenzel

ğŸ“„ How to Learn to Build Apps in 2026 Eric Elliott

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Starry Night 3.9: GitHub-Like Syntax Highlighting â€” GitHubâ€™s own syntax highlighter isnâ€™t open source, but this library is a powerful alternative that tries to get as close as it can, with support for hundreds of languages. Iâ€™ve put a basic Web demo here to show off how to use it on theÂ Web.

Titus Wormer

Extension.js 3: Browser Extension Development Framework â€” Create cross-browser extensions without manual build configuration and develop, build, and preview across browsers with a unified workflow. GitHubÂ repo.

Cezar Augusto et al.

Easily Add Image Editing to your Web App â€” Import pintura, give it an image, and instantly get features like cropping, rotating, and annotation. Try for freeÂ today.

Pintura sponsor

React Aria: Adobe's World-Class React Components â€” React Aria has a fantastic new site and all-new documentation that really sells the entire experience, complete with interactive CSS and Tailwind examples to get started quickly.

Adobe

localspace: Modern localForage-Compatible Storage Toolkit â€” localForage is/was a popular storage library that wrapped various browser storage APIs with a simple, localStorage-like API. It hasnâ€™t been updated for years, though, and â€œlocalspace exists to bridge thatÂ gapâ€.

Michael Lin

  • â­ p5.js v2.2 â€“ The powerful JavaScript visual/creative coding toolkit now includes WebGPU mode as a core feature (explained well here and here).

  • ğŸ¥ Mediabunny 1.29.0 â€“ The TypeScript media toolkit adds support for reading and writing MPEG Transport Stream (.ts) files. Demo site.

  • Prettier 3.8 â€“ The opinionated code formatter adds full support for Angular 21.1 which was released lastÂ week.

  • LogTape 2.0 â€“ Simple logging library for all major JSÂ runtimes. Changelog.

  • â˜ï¸ vue-tel-input 9.6 â€“ Telephone number input for Vue.Â (Demo.)

  • d3-3d 2.0 â€“ D3-powered visualizations, but projected intoÂ 3D.

  • Convert 6.0 â€“ Small, fast library for type-safe unitÂ conversions.

  • SuperDiff 4.0 â€“ Rich readable diffs for arrays andÂ objects.

  • Jasmine 6.0 â€“ Long-standing JavaScript BDDÂ framework.

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

ğŸ”‘ Add API key auth to any JS backend. Clerk handles generation, hashing, scopes, and instant revocation. Free during public beta.

Notion, Dropbox and LaunchDarkly have switched to Meticulous for frontend tests that provide near-exhaustive coverage with zero developer effort. Find outÂ why.

ğŸ› ï¸ Auth0 for AI Agents provides a foundation for developers to build AI agents without compromising security or innovation. StartÂ building.

ğŸ“¢Â  Elsewhere in the ecosystem

Some other interesting tidbits in the broader landscape:

  • ğŸ” The VS Code team has put together a fascinating blog post about how they implemented a new, fast client-side docs search system for the VS Code site using Rust and WebAssembly. You can use their docfind engine for yourself too, and there's a live demo here showing off how fast it is over an index of 50,000 newsÂ articles.

  • ğŸ“Š HTTP Archive has released its latest Web Almanac for 2025 packed with raw stats, trends, and observations about the state of the Web over the past year, covering areas like WebAssembly, performance, and ever-increasing pageÂ weight.

  • A developer makes a prediction that Microsoft will eventually discontinue Windows in favor of a Windows-themed Linux distribution.

  • Things are not looking good for the MySQL project.

  • The State of WebAssembly in 2025 and 2026.

ã€

#â€‹768 â€” January 13, 2026

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Web Dependencies are Broken; Can We Fix Them? â€” Lea, who has worked at the heart of Web Standards for years, delivers a compelling (and educational) call to action about a problem every JavaScript developer has encountered: why is managing dependencies and introducing them into code so unnecessarily messy and what could we do aboutÂ it?

Lea Verou

Build Marketing Sites Like Apple â€” Learn how modern, high-impact marketing sites are built from someone doing it at the highest level. Matias Gonzales, Design Engineer at Vercel, teaches GSAP animation, scroll-driven storytelling, 3D with Three.js, and performance-first techniques used on award-winningÂ sites.

Frontend Masters sponsor

IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸ“º The full set of React Conf 2025 videos is now online, made up of 25 talks and 23 interviews, including one with four members of the core team.

  • There's a tiny update in the Deno-vs-Oracle JavaScript trademark dispute with Oracle requesting, and Deno agreeing to, a 60-dayÂ extension. As it stands, the case is set to drag intoÂ 2027.

  • ğŸ“˜ The Concise TypeScript Book is a short, focused TypeScript guide that's open and free toÂ read.

RELEASES:

  • Node.js January 13 2026 Security Releases â€“ Long-awaited security releases of Node.js v20.x, 22.x, 24.x, and 25.x to resolve five differentÂ vulnerabilities.

  • Bun v1.3.6 â€“ Bun.Archive can now work with tar archives, Bun.JSONC supports parsing commented JSON, plus there are many performance optimizations andÂ tweaks.

  • pnpm 10.28 â€“ The efficient package manager adds a beforePacking hook to customize package.json's contents at publish time.

  • Angular 21.1 is expected this week. v21.1 rc0 landed last week teasing some of theÂ updates.

  • Ember 6.9, ESLint v10.0.0 RC0, Rspack 1.7

ğŸ“–Â  Articles and Videos

Date is Out, Temporal is In â€” The Temporal API has been promised as a future API tackling the weaknesses of JavaScriptâ€™s Date for many years now, but finally that future is arriving. Mat leans on numerous examples to show off Date's weaknesses and push Temporalâ€™s strengthsÂ here.

Mat â€œWiltoâ€ Marquis

ğŸ’¡ Temporal's browser support still looks weak, but Chrome 144 â€“ rolling out generally this week â€“ brings full support. Temporal Polyfill also offers a stop-gap while native supportÂ grows.

How Wrong Can a JavaScript Date Calculation Go? â€” â€œthe story of an issue that I faced that will be much easier to handle once Temporal is moreÂ widespread.â€

Phil Nash

Add GitHub, Slack & Google Integrations Without Rebuilding OAuth â€” WorkOS Pipes handles OAuth flows, token refresh, and storage. Users connect via a widget, your app makes one APIÂ call.

WorkOS sponsor

Stop Turning Everything Into Arrays (and Do Less Work Instead) â€” A post showing off iterator helpers, a broadly supported set of methods for working with Iterator objects as a more efficient way of processing data lazily in an iterative (rather than randomly accessed) fashion.

Matt Smith

How to 'Steal' Any React Component â€” A look at how to reproduce a component from a production React app without the original source, using Reactâ€™s internal data structures (via Fiber) and LLMs to reconstructÂ things.

David Fant

ğŸ“„ JavaScript's for-of Loops Are Actually Fast Suren Enfiajyan

ğŸ“„ Why ARM Has a 'JavaScript Instruction' â€“ FJCVTZS, specifically. NotNotP

ğŸ“„ How I Write Custom Elements with lit-html Dave Samaniego

ğŸ“„ document.currentScript is More Useful Than I Thought Chris Coyier

ğŸ“„ What Happened (and What's Happening) to WebAssembly Emnudge

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

memlab 2.0: A Framework for Finding JavaScript Memory Leaks â€” A testing and analysis framework for identifying memory leaks and optimization opportunities that spawned from Facebookâ€™s own approach to optimizing its main app. Write scenarios, and memlab compares heap snapshots, filters memory leaks, and aggregates theÂ results.

Facebook Open Source

The Time-Series Database That Balances Simplicity and Performance â€” Stay Postgres-native with automatic partitioning, 95% compression, and continuous aggregates at productionÂ scale.

Tiger Data (creators of TimescaleDB) sponsor

Fabric.js 7.1: A Powerful SVG Abstraction Library â€” Provides an interactive object model on top of the HTML5 canvas to make it easier to work with multiple visual elements. Ideal for the browser but it works with NodeÂ too.

Fabric.js

Ohm: A Parsing Toolkit for JavaScript and TypeScript â€” Itâ€™s been a few years since we covered this project and itâ€™s come along a lot since. Itâ€™s a library for building PEG-based parsers you can use in interpreters, compilers, analysis tools, etc. and you can even play with its grammarÂ online.

Warth, Dubroy, et al.

Superdiff 3.2: Compares Two Arrays or Objects and Return a Diff â€” Got two similar objects or arrays and want to see the underlying differences? Superdiff's recent updates boost performance, add support for streamed input and using a worker for more efficient diffing in a separateÂ thread.

antoine

  • JavaScriptKit 0.38 â€“ Swift framework to interact with JavaScript viaÂ WebAssembly.

  • ğŸµ alphaTab 1.8 â€“ Music notation and guitar tab rendering library.

  • Neo.mjs v11.20 â€“ Multi-threaded application engine for theÂ Web.

  • Monio 0.70.0 â€“ Kyle Simpson's IO monadÂ implementation.

  • Ant Design 6.2 â€“ UI design language and React UI library.

  • xstyled 4.1 â€“ Utility-first CSS-in-JS framework for React.

  • Jint 4.5 â€“ JavaScript interpreter for .NET.

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

âš¡ï¸Add lightning-fast barcode & QR scanning to your web app with STRICH, a lean JS library. Simple, predictable pricing. Free trial andÂ demo!

Only fools write manual tests â€“ modern engineering teams like Notion, Dropbox and Lattice use Meticulous to maintain E2E UI tests covering every edge case of your webÂ app.

ğŸš€ Auth0 for AI Agents is the complete auth solution for building AI agents more securely. Start buildingÂ today.

ğŸ“¢Â  Elsewhere in the ecosystem

Some other interesting tidbits in the broader landscape:

  • ğŸ¤– Even Linus Torvalds is 'vibe coding' now. He's been using Google's Antigravity tool to create some digital soundÂ effects.

  • GitHub is planning to implement 'staged publishing' for npm packages in 2026 as a way to introduce a review step before releases goÂ live.

  • ğŸ—“ï¸ The Astro team shares a full 2025 year in review post. It's been a big year for the popularÂ framework.

  • Anil Dash shares the story of how Markdown took over the world.

  • The results of the State of HTML 2025 survey are now available.

  • TIL that Deno, the JavaScript runtime, is being distributed on Python's PyPI to make it easier for Python apps to call out to JavaScript asÂ needed.

  • In 2025, Bun was the third largest contributor to JavaScriptCore, the JavaScript engine powering both Safari and Bun.
